translated: Chapter 24: Explaining the Unification of the Teachings, Volume 52
Composed by the Sage NÄgÃ¢rjuna
Translated by Tripiá¹­aka Master KumÄrajÄ«va of the Later Qin from Kucha
SÅ«tra: At that time, the venerable PÅ«rá¹‡a MaitrÄyaniputra addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
The Buddha has had SubhÅ«ti expound prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ for the bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas. Now, he expounds the MahÄyÄna.
SubhÅ«ti addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
When I expound the MahÄyÄna, will it not be apart from prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ?
The Buddha said:
No, it is not.ğŸ”½
SubhÅ«ti!
Your expounding of the MahÄyÄna accords with prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ and is not apart from prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.
Why is it so?

All the wholesome dharmas and the dharmas that assist the path, whether the dharmas of the Å›rÄvakas, the dharmas of the pratyekabuddhas, the dharmas of the bodhisattvas, or the dharmas of the buddhas, all these dharmas are included within prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.
SubhÅ«ti addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!

What are the wholesome dharmas and the dharmas that assist the path, the dharmas of the Å›rÄvakas, the dharmas of the pratyekabuddhas, the dharmas of the bodhisattvas, and the dharmas of the buddhas that are all included within prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ?
The Buddha told SubhÅ«ti:

They are the perfection of giving, the perfection of morality, the perfection of patience, the perfection of diligence, the perfection of meditation, and the perfection of wisdom; the four establishments of mindfulness, the four right efforts, the four bases of supernatural power, the five faculties, the five powers, the seven factors of awakening, and the eightfold noble path; the doors of liberation of emptiness, signlessness, and wishlessness; the ten powers of the Buddha, the four fearlessnesses, the four unobstructed understandings, great compassion, the eighteen distinctive abilities of the Buddha, the characteristic of being free from error, and always practicing abandonment.
SubhÅ«ti!

These and other wholesome dharmas, auxiliary dharmas, whether dharmas of the Å›rÄvakas, dharmas of the pratyekabuddhas, dharmas of the bodhisattvas, or dharmas of the buddhas, are all included within the perfection of wisdom.
SubhÅ«ti!
whether it is the MahÄyÄna, or the perfections of prajÃ±Ä, dhyÄna, vigor, patience, morality, and giving;

whether it is form, feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness, eye, form, eye-consciousness, eye-contact, and the feelings produced by the condition of eye-contact, up to mind, mental objects, mind-consciousness, mind-contact, and the feelings produced by the condition of mind-contact;
whether it is the earth element up to the consciousness element;
whether it is the four establishments of mindfulness up to the eightfold noble path;
whether it is the doors of liberation of emptiness, signlessness, and wishlessness;

whether it is wholesome dharmas, whether with outflows or without outflows, whether conditioned or unconditioned, whether the truth of suffering, the truth of accumulation, the truth of cessation, or the truth of the path, whether the desire realm, the form realm, or the formless realm, whether internal emptiness up to the emptiness of non-existence of own-characteristics;
whether it is the doors of concentration or the doors of dhÄraá¹‡Ä«;
the ten powers of the Buddha up to the eighteen distinctive abilities of the Buddha;

if the Buddha, the Buddha-Dharma, the nature of dharmas, thusness, the limit of reality, the inconceivable nature, and nirvana - all these dharmas are neither conjoined nor dispersed, are formless, shapeless, and unobstructing, and are of one mark, which is to say, the mark of no mark.
SubhÅ«ti!
For this reason, what you have said about the MahÄyÄna accords with prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.
Why is it so?
SubhÅ«ti!
The MahÄyÄna is not different from prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, and prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ is not different from the MahÄyÄna. PrajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ and the MahÄyÄna are non-dual and indivisible;
dÄna-pÄramitÄ is not different from the MahÄyÄna, and the MahÄyÄna is not different from dÄna-pÄramitÄ. DÄna-pÄramitÄ and the MahÄyÄna are non-dual and indivisible;
up to and including dhyÄna-pÄramitÄ, it is the same. SubhÅ«ti!

The four establishments of mindfulness are no different from the Great Vehicle, the Great Vehicle is no different from the four establishments of mindfulness, the four establishments of mindfulness and the Great Vehicle are non-dual and indivisible;

Up to the eighteen distinctive abilities of the Buddha are no different from the Great Vehicle, the Great Vehicle is no different from the eighteen distinctive abilities of the Buddha, the eighteen distinctive abilities of the Buddha and the Great Vehicle are non-dual and indivisible.
For this reason, SubhÅ«ti!
You say that the Great Vehicle is precisely speaking prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.
[The Treatise] says:
Although PÅ«rá¹‡a himself has no doubts, he asks about it for the sake of the newly initiated and slow-witted ones who do not understand that the meaning is one but the names are different.
SubhÅ«ti then brings up the matter and asks the Buddha:
The Buddha's teachings are very profound. Will there be no error in what I have said?
The Buddha replies:
Your explanation of the Great Vehicle accords with prajÃ±Ä and is without error.

This meaning has already been discussed earlier, but now the Buddha explains the corresponding causes and conditions, namely, all wholesome dharmas included in the three vehicles are all gathered in the perfection of prajÃ±Ä.
Why is this so?
Because all wholesome dharmas of the three vehicles are for the sake of nirvÄá¹‡a.
There are three gates to nirvÄá¹‡a:
All dharmas enter the gate of emptiness, the gate of signlessness, and the gate of wishlessness.
Just as precepts can give rise to meditative concentration, and meditative concentration can give rise to true wisdom, because one is not attached to the world.
What are the auxiliary dharmas of the three vehicles that are included in prajÃ±Ä?

They are the six perfections, the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment, the three gates of liberation, the ten powers of the Buddha, the four fearlessnesses, the four unobstructed understandings, great compassion, the eighteen distinctive abilities, the characteristic of being free from error, and always practicing abandonment.

Among them, the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment and the three gates of liberation are the common teachings of the Three Vehicles, the six perfections are the teachings of the bodhisattvas, and the ten powers up to the constant practice of abandonment are the teachings of the Buddha.
Some people say:
The six perfections may be complete or incomplete.
The incomplete ones are common teachings with the Two Vehicles, the complete ones are unique to the bodhisattvas.
Moreover, the emptiness of the MahÄyÄna and the emptiness of prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ are the same in meaning of emptiness, so SubhÅ«ti follows without error.
Just as prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ is empty, the five perfections up to suchness, the nature of dharmas, the realm of reality, the inconceivable nature, and nirvÄá¹‡a are also like this.
Moreover, from prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ up to nirvÄá¹‡a, they are all non-combined, non-dispersed, formless, shapeless, and unimpeded, with a single characteristic, which is to say, no characteristics.

Because they have the same characteristic, it is said that the MahÄyÄna is the prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, and the MahÄyÄna and prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ are non-dual and indivisible.ğŸ”½Chapter 25: The Ten Non-existences
The MahÄprajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ ÅšÄstra, Explanation of the Chapter on the Ten Non-existences, Part 25 [SÅ«tra] SubhÅ«ti, the one with wisdom, said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
The beginning point of a bodhisattva-mahÄsattva cannot be apprehended, the end point cannot be apprehended, and the middle point cannot be apprehended.
Because form is boundless, one should know that bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are also boundless;
Because feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness are boundless, one should know that bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are also boundless.
Form is a bodhisattva-mahÄsattva, but this also cannot be apprehended;
Feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness are a bodhisattva-mahÄsattva, but this also cannot be apprehended.
Thus, World-Honored One!
In all kinds and all places, a bodhisattva cannot be apprehended.
World-Honored One!
Which bodhisattva-mahÄsattva should I teach prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ?
World-Honored One!
The bodhisattva-mahÄsattva is merely a name.
Just as the name 'I' is spoken, the 'I' is ultimately unborn.
Just as with the 'I', all dharmas are also like this, without self-nature.
What kind of form is ultimately unborn?
What kind of feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness are ultimately unborn?
World-Honored One!
This ultimate non-arising is not called form;
this ultimate non-arising is not called feeling, perception, formation, or consciousness.
World-Honored One!
If a dharma is ultimately unborn, to whom should one teach prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ?
Apart from the ultimately unborn, there is also no bodhisattva who practices for anuttarÄ-samyak-saá¹ƒbodhi.

If a bodhisattva hears this teaching and their mind does not become deflated, regretful, frightened, terrified, or fearful, one should know that this bodhisattva-mahÄsattva is able to practice prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.
ÅšÄriputra asked:
SubhÅ«ti,
why do you say that the prior limit of the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva cannot be apprehended, the subsequent limit cannot be apprehended, and the middle cannot be apprehended?
SubhÅ«ti,
why do you say that because form is boundless, one should know that the bodhisattva is also boundless;
because feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness are boundless, one should know that the bodhisattva is also boundless?
SubhÅ«ti,
why do you say that form is the bodhisattva, and this also cannot be apprehended;
feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness are the bodhisattva, and this also cannot be apprehended?
SubhÅ«ti,
For what causes and conditions does it say, 'In all kinds of ways, in all places, the bodhisattva cannot be found, so which bodhisattva should be taught prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ'?
SubhÅ«ti!
For what causes and conditions does it say, 'The bodhisattva-mahÄsattva is merely a name'?
SubhÅ«ti!
For what causes and conditions does it say, 'Just as my name is spoken, I am ultimately unborn;
Just as with me, all dharmas are also like this, without self-nature.
What kind of form is ultimately unborn, what kind of feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness are ultimately unborn'?
SubhÅ«ti!
For what causes and conditions does it say, 'That which is ultimately unborn is not called form;
That which is ultimately unborn is not called feeling, perception, formation, or consciousness'?
SubhÅ«ti!
For what causes and conditions does it say, 'If a dharma is ultimately unborn, to whom should prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ be taught'?
SubhÅ«ti!
For what causes and conditions does it say 'apart from the non-arising of the absolute, there is also no bodhisattva practicing supreme, perfect enlightenment'?
SubhÅ«ti!

For what causes and conditions does it say 'if a bodhisattva hears this teaching and their mind does not sink, does not regret, is not frightened, is not terrified, and is not afraid, if they are able to practice in this way, this is called a bodhisattva-mahÄsattva practicing prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ'?
At that time, SubhÅ«ti replied to ÅšÄriputra, saying:
Because sentient beings do not exist, the prior limit of the bodhisattva cannot be apprehended;
because sentient beings are empty, the prior limit of the bodhisattva cannot be apprehended;
because sentient beings are isolated, the prior limit of the bodhisattva cannot be apprehended.
ÅšÄriputra!
Because form does not exist, the prior limit of the bodhisattva cannot be apprehended;
because feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness do not exist, the prior limit of the bodhisattva cannot be apprehended.
Because form is empty, the prior limit of the bodhisattva cannot be apprehended;
Because feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness are empty, the past limit of a bodhisattva cannot be apprehended.
Because form is isolated, the past limit of a bodhisattva cannot be apprehended;
because feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness are isolated, the past limit of a bodhisattva cannot be apprehended.
ÅšÄriputra!
Because the nature of form is non-existent, the past limit of a bodhisattva cannot be apprehended;
because the nature of feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness is non-existent, the past limit of a bodhisattva cannot be apprehended.
ÅšÄriputra!
Because the perfection of giving does not exist, the past limit of a bodhisattva cannot be apprehended;

because the perfection of morality, the perfection of patience, the perfection of perseverance, the perfection of concentration, and the perfection of wisdom do not exist, the past limit of a bodhisattva cannot be apprehended.
Why is it so?
ÅšÄriputra!
In emptiness, the past limit cannot be apprehended, the future limit cannot be apprehended, and the present limit cannot be apprehended;
emptiness is not different from a bodhisattva, and a bodhisattva is not different from the past limit.
ÅšÄriputra!
Emptiness, bodhisattvas, and the past - these dharmas are non-dual and indivisible.
For this reason, ÅšÄriputra!
The past of a bodhisattva cannot be apprehended.
ÅšÄriputra!

Because the perfection of giving is empty, because the perfection of giving is separated, because the nature of the perfection of giving is non-existent, the past of a bodhisattva cannot be apprehended;
the perfection of morality, the perfection of patience, the perfection of vigor, the perfection of meditation;

because the perfection of wisdom is empty, because the perfection of wisdom is separated, because the nature of the perfection of wisdom is non-existent, the past of a bodhisattva cannot be apprehended.
Why is it so?
ÅšÄriputra!
In emptiness, the past cannot be apprehended, the future cannot be apprehended, and the present cannot be apprehended;
emptiness is not different from a bodhisattva, and a bodhisattva is also not different from the past.
ÅšÄriputra!
emptiness, bodhisattva, and the pastâ€”these dharmas are non-dual and indivisible.
For this reason, ÅšÄriputra,
the past limit of the bodhisattva cannot be apprehended.
Furthermore, ÅšÄriputra,
because internal emptiness does not exist, the past limit of the bodhisattva cannot be apprehended;
up to because the emptiness of the non-existence of own-characteristics does not exist, the past limit of the bodhisattva cannot be apprehended.

Because internal emptiness is empty, because internal emptiness is isolated, because the intrinsic nature of internal emptiness does not exist, up to because the emptiness of the non-existence of own-characteristics is empty, because it is isolated, because the intrinsic nature does not exist, the past limit of the bodhisattva cannot be apprehended.
The rest is as explained above.
Furthermore, ÅšÄriputra,
because the four establishments of mindfulness do not exist, the past limit of the bodhisattva cannot be apprehended;
because the four establishments of mindfulness are empty, because they are isolated, because the intrinsic nature does not exist, the past limit of the bodhisattva cannot be apprehended.
Up to because the eighteen distinctive abilities of a buddha do not exist, the past limit of the bodhisattva cannot be apprehended;
Because the eighteen distinctive abilities of the Buddha are empty, absent, and essentially non-existent, the past limit of the bodhisattva cannot be apprehended.
The rest is as explained above.
For these reasons, ÅšÄriputra,
the past limit of the bodhisattva cannot be apprehended.
Furthermore, ÅšÄriputra,
because all the gateways to samÄdhi and all the dhÄraá¹‡Ä« gateways do not exist, the past limit of the bodhisattva cannot be apprehended;
because the gateways to samÄdhi and dhÄraá¹‡Ä« gateways are empty, absent, and essentially non-existent, the past limit of the bodhisattva cannot be apprehended.
The rest is as explained above.
Furthermore, ÅšÄriputra,
because the nature of dharmas does not exist, the past limit of the bodhisattva cannot be apprehended;
because the nature of dharmas is empty, absent, and essentially non-existent, the past limit of the bodhisattva cannot be apprehended.
The rest is as explained above.
Furthermore, ÅšÄriputra,

As there is no existence, emptiness, separation, and naturelessness, the ultimate reality has no existence, emptiness, separation, and naturelessness, the inconceivable nature has no existence, emptiness, separation, and naturelessness, the prior limit of the bodhisattva cannot be apprehended.
The rest is as explained above.
Furthermore, ÅšÄriputra!
Because the Å›rÄvaka has no existence, the prior limit of the bodhisattva cannot be apprehended;

because the Å›rÄvaka is empty, separated, and has no nature, the prior limit of the bodhisattva cannot be apprehended.ğŸ”½Because the pratyekabuddha has no existence, is empty, separated, and has no nature, the prior limit of the bodhisattva cannot be apprehended.
Because the Buddha has no existence, is empty, separated, and has no nature, the prior limit of the bodhisattva cannot be apprehended.
Because unsurpassed, perfect enlightenment has no existence and so forth up to no nature, the prior limit of the bodhisattva cannot be apprehended.
Furthermore, because the knowledge of all modes does not exist, up to because its nature does not exist, the past limit of the bodhisattva cannot be apprehended.
Why is it so?
ÅšÄriputra!
Emptiness cannot be apprehended in the past, future, or present, and the bodhisattva cannot be apprehended.
ÅšÄriputra!
Emptiness is not different from the bodhisattva, nor is it different from the past;
emptiness, the bodhisattva, and the past - these dharmas are non-dual and indivisible.
For this reason, ÅšÄriputra!
The past limit of the bodhisattva cannot be apprehended, and the future and present limits are also like this.ğŸ”½[Discourse]
Question:
Above it was already said that the bodhisattva and the name of the bodhisattva cannot be apprehended, for whom is the perfection of wisdom taught? Why is it said again now?
Answer:
This question should not be asked!
SubhÅ«ti is foremost in practicing emptiness and always delights in speaking of emptiness;
If there is anything to be said, it is always to benefit sentient beings through the gate of emptiness.
Furthermore, above it was briefly explained, and here the ten kinds of non-attainability of the bodhisattva are extensively distinguished.
If practitioners contemplate the emptiness of all dharmas, they accord with signlessness and non-action;
Because of the mind of non-action, they do not wish to do anything. They are unable to benefit themselves, let alone benefit others!
If one abides in the mind of self, one can distinguish the characteristics of good and bad dharmas, accumulate good dharmas, and abandon bad dharmas;
Now the Buddha says:
In prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, one should not conceive of a self, nor should one distinguish dharmas. One should only practice all good.
This matter is difficult.
The practitioner thinks like this:
If there is no self, for whom should one cultivate goodness?
Previously there was a self, but now because of prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, it does not exist. The mind gives rise to sorrow.
Therefore SubhÅ«ti repeats and says:
I have never existed from the beginning, and it is not that I existed before but now do not.
The practitioner is like this, originally non-existent, and now nothing is lost, therefore there is nothing to worry about.
It is like a tree with deep roots, which cannot be cut down with one stroke, but requires much ax effort to cut it down;
The emptiness of the bodhisattva is also like this, it cannot be attained by one explanation, and for this reason it is extensively distinguished.
When SubhÅ«ti asked the Buddha, he thought like this:
If there is a definite bodhisattva dharma, it should be common to the three times.
Now there are no bodhisattvas in the past world.
Why is it so?
Because there is no beginning in the past world.
The future world is also like this, because there are no causes and conditions yet.
Because the past and future depend on each other, there is a present. If there is no past and future, then there is no present.
If one says the five aggregates are the bodhisattva;

The five aggregates are boundless, as explained in various ways above. Because the five aggregates are ultimately empty, they are immeasurable and boundless. Because they are immeasurable and boundless, they are the same as unconditioned dharmas.
If the bodhisattva is boundless, this is not so!
For this reason, the bodhisattva cannot be attained, for whom should it be explained?
Constantly seeking the bodhisattva everywhere, in all ways, and at all times, he cannot be attained, for whom should it be explained?
Just as I am ultimately unborn and empty and non-existent, the five aggregates are also like this, ultimately unborn and non-existent.
Since there are no sentient beings and no dharmas of the five aggregates, how can there be a bodhisattva?
Question:
The sentient beings and dharmas of the five aggregates are ultimately unborn. Understanding this Dharma is precisely the bodhisattva?
Answer:
Ultimately unborn is not called form, not called feeling, perception, formation, or consciousness.
Why is this?
The five aggregates are the characteristic of arising, but in the ultimately unborn, there is no such discrimination.
The five aggregates are ultimately unborn, and cannot be taught;
Apart from the ultimately unborn, there is also no bodhisattva practice. To whom should it be taught?
If a bodhisattva hears this and is neither frightened nor afraid, this is being able to practice the bodhisattva path.
Question:
I and the bodhisattva are one and the same thing, so why use me as a metaphor for the bodhisattva?
Answer:
In this prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, all dharmas are empty. Beginners cannot be taught emptiness right away!
First, one should distinguish between sin and merit, abandon sin and cultivate merit;

The fruits and rewards of merit are impermanent. Because they are impermanent, they give rise to suffering. Therefore, one abandons merit, becomes weary with the world, seeks the Way, and enters nirvÄá¹‡a.
At that time, one should think like this:
Because of me, afflictions arise. I am sought in the six consciousnesses but cannot be found. It is only due to inversion that I cling to the self.
Therefore, it is easy to understand non-self and easy to accept the teachings.
If one says form is empty, it is difficult to understand;
although one hears the teaching of emptiness with the ears, the eyes constantly see reality.
Therefore, the self in evil offenses is refuted first, and then all dharmas are refuted.

All disciples of the Buddha who have attained the Way know and realize non-self by themselves. Those who have not attained the Way believe in the emptiness of other dharmas, but they cannot believe in non-self as much. Therefore, non-self is used as a metaphor.
Here, SubhÅ«ti speaks of the emptiness of all dharmas, pushing for the non-existence of bodhisattvas, using non-self as a metaphor;
using the small to illustrate the great, like using molasses to illustrate nectar.
Question:
ÅšÄriputra knows the meaning of emptiness and non-self, so why does he repeatedly ask questions?
Answer:

SubhÅ«ti is a Å›rÄvaka, whose virtue is not as good as that of a bodhisattva. Yet he spoke of the profound prajÃ±Ä in front of the Buddha. The newly practicing bodhisattvas may give rise to doubts in their minds.
Although the Buddha said above, You speak MahÄyÄna in accordance with prajÃ±Ä, he still thought that the Buddha was following SubhÅ«ti.
ÅšÄriputra wanted to cut off this doubt, so he asked.
Furthermore, the Buddha wanted to discuss prajÃ±Ä with SubhÅ«ti until the end;
Therefore, ÅšÄriputra asked questions about various matters, causing SubhÅ«ti to skillfully distinguish the profound meaning and make the multitude respect and believe.
For this reason, he asked:
In the past, bodhisattvas could not be attained, and so forth, without fear or terror.
SubhÅ«ti answered the meaning:
I, sentient beings, and people are one thing.
When one has not attained the Way, one is called an ordinary person;
From the initial entry into the Way up to arhatship, one is called a Å›rÄvaka;
Observing the Dharma of causes and conditions, understanding emptiness a little deeply, and having a little compassion for sentient beings, one is called a pratyekabuddha;

Deeply entering the Dharma of emptiness, practicing the six perfections, and having great compassion, this is called a bodhisattva person - because of the difference in merits, the name is also different.

Just as I, sentient beings, and people are one thing, but because of seeing with the eyes, it is called the seer, because of being obtained by the mind, it is called the knower, and because of experiencing suffering and pleasure, it is called the experiencer.
This is I, sentient beings, people, and so forth. Various reasons have already been explained as non-existent, therefore bodhisattvas should also be non-existent.
Therefore SubhÅ«ti said to ÅšÄriputra:
Because sentient beings do not exist, there are no bodhisattvas in the three times.
Question:
If there is a bodhisattva in the combination of the five aggregates, the bodhisattva should not exist, but the five aggregates should exist!
Answer:

In order to destroy this, it is said that there are no sentient beings and no self. Because there is no self, the five aggregates belong to nothing. Because they belong to nothing, they are empty. Because they are empty, there are no bodhisattvas.
Question:
If the five aggregates are empty, is emptiness itself the bodhisattva?
Answer:
The emptiness of the five aggregates is also not the bodhisattva, because emptiness is non-existent and non-discriminatory.
The five aggregates are detached, and the nature of the five aggregates is also without a bodhisattva.
If it is said that there is no bodhisattva, then the three times are all non-existent.
Contemplating these five aggregates and other worldly dharmas, and the six perfections and other path dharmas, is called the bodhisattva;
Because these dharmas are empty, the bodhisattva is also empty.
Here the Buddha himself explains the reason:

The emptiness of all dharmas is not different from the bodhisattva, the bodhisattva is not different from emptiness, the emptiness of the bodhisattva and the emptiness of the three times are non-dual and undifferentiated.
From the six perfections up to omniscience, practicing these dharmas is called the bodhisattva;
Because these dharmas are empty, the bodhisattva is also empty.
Here, the emptiness of dharmas is attained by Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas through this emptiness, they are called Å›rÄvaka and pratyekabuddha persons;
The person-emptiness of Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas is the same as that of bodhisattvas.
[Sutra] As ÅšÄriputra said:
Because form is boundless, you should know that bodhisattvas are also boundless;
Because feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness are boundless, you should know that bodhisattvas are also boundless.
ÅšÄriputra!
Form is like empty space, feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness are like empty space.
Why is it so?
ÅšÄriputra!
The limits of empty space cannot be found, nor can its middle be found. Because there are no limits or middle, it is simply called empty space.
In this way, ÅšÄriputra!
The limits of form cannot be found, nor can its middle be found. Because form is empty, there are no limits or middle in emptiness;
Feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness;
The limits of consciousness cannot be found, nor can its middle be found. Because consciousness is empty, there are no limits or middle in emptiness.
For this reason, ÅšÄriputra!
Because form is boundless, you should know that bodhisattvas are also boundless;
Because feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness are boundless, you should know that bodhisattvas are also boundless.
Up to the eighteen distinctive abilities of the Buddha are also like this.
As ÅšÄriputra said:
'Form is the bodhisattva, but this cannot be apprehended;
Feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness are the bodhisattva, but this also cannot be apprehended.'
ÅšÄriputra!
Form and the characteristics of form are empty, feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness and the characteristics of consciousness are empty;
The perfection of giving and the characteristics of the perfection of giving are empty, up to the perfection of wisdom it is also like this;
Inner emptiness and the characteristics of inner emptiness are empty, up to emptiness of non-existence and existence and the characteristics of emptiness of non-existence and existence are empty;

The four establishments of mindfulness and the characteristics of the four establishments of mindfulness are empty, up to the eighteen distinctive abilities of the Buddha and the characteristics of the eighteen distinctive abilities of the Buddha are empty;
Like the nature of dharmas and the limit of reality, the nature of the inconceivable is empty of the nature of the inconceivable;
The door of concentration and the characteristics of the door of concentration are empty, the door of dhÄraá¹‡Ä« and the characteristics of the door of dhÄraá¹‡Ä« are empty;

Omniscience and the characteristics of omniscience are empty, the cognition of the path and the characteristics of the cognition of the path are empty, the cognition of all aspects and the characteristics of the cognition of all aspects are empty;

The vehicle of the hearers and the characteristics of the vehicle of the hearers are empty, the vehicle of the solitary buddhas and the characteristics of the vehicle of the solitary buddhas are empty, the vehicle of the buddhas and the characteristics of the vehicle of the buddhas are empty;

The person of the hearers and the characteristics of the person of the hearers are empty, the solitary buddha and the characteristics of the solitary buddha are empty, the buddha and the characteristics of the buddha are empty.
Form cannot be apprehended in emptiness, feeling, perception, mental formations, or consciousness cannot be apprehended.
For this reason, ÅšÄriputra,ğŸ”½form is the bodhisattva, and this also cannot be apprehended;
feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness are the bodhisattva, and this also cannot be apprehended.
As ÅšÄriputra said:
'For what reasons is the bodhisattva not to be found in any kind, in any place? What kind of bodhisattva should be taught prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ?'
ÅšÄriputra!
Form is not to be found in form;
form is not to be found in feeling.
Feeling is not to be found in feeling;
feeling is not to be found in form;
feeling is not to be found in perception.
Perception is not to be found in perception;
perception is not to be found in form or feeling;
perception is not to be found in mental formations.
Mental formations are not to be found in mental formations;
mental formations are not to be found in form, feeling, or perception;
mental formations are not to be found in consciousness.
Consciousness is not to be found in consciousness, consciousness is not to be found in form, feeling, perception, or mental formations.
ÅšÄriputra!ğŸ”½The eye is not to be found in the eye;
the eye is not to be found in the ear.
The ear cannot be found within the ear;
the ear cannot be found within the eye;
the ear cannot be found within the nose.
The nose cannot be found within the nose;
the nose cannot be found within the eye or ear;
the nose cannot be found within the tongue.
The tongue cannot be found within the tongue;
the tongue cannot be found within the eye, ear, or nose;
the tongue cannot be found within the body.
The body cannot be found within the body;
the body cannot be found within the eye, ear, nose, tongue, or mind;
the body cannot be found within the mind.
The mind cannot be found within the mind;
the mind cannot be found within the eye, ear, nose, tongue, or body.
The six sense bases, six consciousnesses, six contacts, and six kinds of contact-born feelings are also like this.

from the perfection of giving to the perfection of wisdom, from the emptiness of internal phenomena to the emptiness of the essential nature of non-existent phenomena, from the four establishments of mindfulness to the eighteen distinctive qualities of the Buddha, from all the doors of concentration to all the doors of mnemonic incantation, from the nature of phenomena to the teachings of the solitary buddhas, from the first stage to the tenth stage, from omniscience to the knowledge of paths and the knowledge of all modes of knowledge, are also like this;
from the stream-enterer to the arhat, from the solitary buddha to the bodhisattva and the Buddha, are also like this.
The bodhisattva cannot be found within the bodhisattva;
the bodhisattva cannot be found within the perfection of wisdom.
The perfection of wisdom cannot be found within the perfection of wisdom;
the perfection of wisdom cannot be found within the bodhisattva;
within the perfection of wisdom, the existence of guiding is unobtainable.
Within guiding, the existence of guiding is unobtainable;
In the teaching and transforming, the bodhisattva and prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ do not exist and cannot be attained.
ÅšÄriputra!
In this way, all dharmas do not exist and cannot be attained.
For this reason, in all aspects and in all places, the bodhisattva cannot be attained. What kind of bodhisattva should be taught prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ?
As ÅšÄriputra said:
'For what causes and conditions is it said that the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva is only a provisional name?'
ÅšÄriputra!
Form is a provisional name, feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness are provisional names;
The name of form is not form, the name of feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness is not feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness.
Why is it so?
Name and the characteristics of name are empty;
If empty, then it is not a bodhisattva.
For this reason, ÅšÄriputra!
The bodhisattva is only a provisional name.
Furthermore, ÅšÄriputra!
The pÄramitÄ of giving is only a name;
In the name, there is no perfection of giving, and in the perfection of giving, there is no name.
For this reason, the bodhisattva is only a provisional name.
The perfection of morality, the perfection of patience, the perfection of diligence, the perfection of meditation,
and the perfection of wisdom are only names;
in the name, there is no perfection of wisdom, and in the perfection of wisdom, there is no name.
For this reason, the bodhisattva is only a provisional name.
ÅšÄriputra!

The emptiness of internal phenomena is only a name, up to the emptiness of the essential nature of non-existent phenomena is only a name. In the name, there is no emptiness of internal phenomena, and in the emptiness of internal phenomena, there is no name.
Why is it so?
The name and the emptiness of internal phenomena are both unobtainable.
Up to the emptiness of the essential nature of non-existent phenomena is also like this.
For this reason, ÅšÄriputra!
The bodhisattva is only a provisional name.
ÅšÄriputra!
The four establishments of mindfulness are merely names, up to the eighteen distinctive abilities of the Buddha are merely names;
all the doors of samÄdhi, all the dhÄraá¹‡Ä« doors, up to the knowledge of all modes is also like this.
For this reason, ÅšÄriputra,
I say that the bodhisattva is merely a provisional name.
As ÅšÄriputra said:
'For what causes and conditions do you say that my name is ultimately non-arisen?'
ÅšÄriputra!
Since the self is ultimately unobtainable, how can there be arising?
Up to the knower and seer are ultimately unobtainable, how can there be arising?
ÅšÄriputra!
Since form is ultimately unobtainable, how can there be arising?
Since feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness are ultimately unobtainable, how can there be arising?
Since the eye is ultimately unobtainable, up to since the feeling that arises from the condition of contact with the mind is ultimately unobtainable, how can there be arising?
The perfection of giving is ultimately unobtainable, up to the perfection of wisdom is ultimately unobtainable, how can there be birth?
Inner emptiness is ultimately unobtainable, up to the emptiness of non-existence and existence is ultimately unobtainable, how can there be birth?
The four mindfulnesses are ultimately unobtainable, up to the eighteen distinctive abilities of the Buddha are ultimately unobtainable, how can there be birth?
The doors of samÄdhi and dhÄraá¹‡Ä« are ultimately unobtainable, how can there be birth?
The Å›rÄvakas up to the buddhas are ultimately unobtainable, how can there be birth?
For this reason, ÅšÄriputra!
I say:
'Just as my name, I too am ultimately unborn.'
[Treatise] Question:
The mind and mental factors are formless and invisible, so they can be boundless;
Form has form and is visible, how can it be boundless?
Answer:
There is no place where form does not exist, and it cannot be measured in terms of distance, weight, or heaviness.
As the Buddha said:
The four great elements exist everywhere, and therefore they are called great;
They cannot be limited by the five sense faculties, and they cannot be measured in terms of their quantity, weight, or heaviness by a bushel or scale. Therefore, it is said that form is boundless.
Furthermore, this form, in the past, its beginning cannot be found;
In the future, there is no limit to the number of Ganges sands of eons during which form will exist, and therefore it has no end;
Since there is no beginning or end, the middle also does not exist.
Furthermore, end refers to the characteristics of form;
This form is analyzed and dispersed, and the end cannot be found, and it has no fundamental characteristics.
Furthermore, unconditioned dharmas do not arise or cease, and therefore they are innumerable, immeasurable, and boundless;
By contemplating form as empty with the view of the emptiness of dharmas, it is the same as space and unconditioned dharmas.
In immeasurable, innumerable, boundless dharmas, even the smallest particle cannot be obtained, let alone a bodhisattva!
Therefore, it is said that the five aggregates are boundless, and bodhisattvas are also boundless.
Just as form is boundless, up to the eighteen distinctive abilities of a buddha are also like this. The distinctions according to characteristics are as explained above.
Because the five aggregates are immeasurable, innumerable, and boundless, one cannot say that form is a bodhisattva;
The four aggregates are also like this.ğŸ”½Furthermore, if form is apart from the mind and mental factors, like grass, trees, tiles, and stones, how can it be called a bodhisattva?
If the mind and mental factors are apart from form, they have no basis and nothing they can do. How can they be called a bodhisattva?

Furthermore, the six perfections, the eighteen emptinesses, the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment, the ten powers, up to the eighteen distinctive qualities of the Buddha, suchness, the nature of dharmas, the reality-limit, the inconceivable nature, the three gates of liberation, the dhÄraá¹‡Ä« gateways, the various samÄdhi gateways, omniscience, the knowledge of the path, the knowledge of all modes, the three vehicles, and the people of the three vehiclesâ€”if one cultivates or contemplates these dharmas, this is called a bodhisattva.

These dharmas are all empty because of the emptiness of their own characteristics, namely, the perfection of giving is empty, the characteristics of the perfection of giving are empty, up to the Buddha is empty, the characteristics of the Buddha are empty.
As for all places, they are the five aggregates, the twelve sense fields, the eighteen elements, up to omniscience.
As for omniscience, it is the eighteen emptinesses and the three gates of liberation.
The contemplation of prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, whether it is considered to be permanent or impermanent, enters one gate, two gates, up to immeasurable gates, and so forth. This is called omniscience.
The bodhisattva cannot be found through seeking.
Moreover, within one's own Dharma, there is no one's own Dharma, nor is there another's Dharma.
As it is said here:
Form cannot be found within form;
form cannot be found within feeling.
Feeling cannot be found within feeling;
feeling cannot be found within form;
up to prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ cannot be found within prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ;
up to within teaching, teaching cannot be found.
There are only names means that the five aggregates are destroyed and dispersed, no different from empty space.
This bodhisattva only has a name, like an illusory person, and is given a name again within a false name.
SubhÅ«ti said to ÅšÄriputra:
Not only is the bodhisattva a false name, the five aggregates are all also false names;
within false names, the characteristics of false names cannot be found, they all enter the ultimate truth.
If it were empty in this way, it would not be a bodhisattva.
Furthermore, the six perfections up to omniscience, by practicing these dharmas, are called bodhisattvas;
these dharmas are also provisional names, and bodhisattvas are also provisional names, empty and non-existent.
These dharmas and so forth are forcibly given names, existing due to the combination of causes and conditions, but they are not real.
My name is ultimately unborn - this was already explained at the beginning of this chapter.
Here, SubhÅ«ti also destroys the self by means of the emptiness of beings and the emptiness of dharmas, namely:
The self is ultimately unobtainable, up to the knower and seer are unobtainable, so how can there be birth?
The five aggregates are ultimately unobtainable, so how can there be the birth of the five aggregates?
Up to the feeling produced by the condition of mind-contact is ultimately unobtainable, so how can there be birth?
The six perfections are ultimately unobtainable, up to the dhÄraá¹‡Ä« gateways, samÄdhi gateways, Å›rÄvakas, pratyekabuddhas, and buddhas are ultimately unobtainable, so how can there be birth?
If a dharma existed first, then it could be asked about birth;
Since the essence of a dharma did not exist before, how can there be birth?
The sÅ«tra says: As ÅšÄriputra said:
'Just as I am, so are all dharmas, also like this, without intrinsic nature.'
ÅšÄriputra!
All dharmas are born from a combination, thus without intrinsic nature.
ÅšÄriputra!
What is born from a combination without intrinsic nature?
ÅšÄriputra!
Form is born from a combination, thus without intrinsic nature. Feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness are born from a combination, thus without intrinsic nature.
The eye is born from a combination, thus without intrinsic nature, up to the mind is born from a combination, thus without intrinsic nature.

form up to dharmas, the eye element up to the dharma element, the earth element up to the consciousness element, eye contact up to mind contact, and the feelings that arise from the causes and conditions of eye contact up to the feelings that arise from the causes and conditions of mind contact are all born from a combination of causes and have no self-nature.
The perfections of giving up to wisdom are all born from a combination of causes and have no self-nature.
The four establishments of mindfulness up to the eighteen distinctive abilities of the Buddha are all born from a combination of causes and have no self-nature.
Furthermore, ÅšÄriputra!
All dharmas are impermanent and also not lost.
ÅšÄriputra asked SubhÅ«ti:
What dharmas are impermanent and also not lost?
SubhÅ«ti said:
Form is impermanent and also not lost, and feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness are impermanent and also not lost.
Why is it so?
If a dharma is impermanent, then it is a characteristic of change, and it is a characteristic of emptiness.
For this reason, ÅšÄriputra!
All conditioned dharmas are impermanent and also not lost.
Whether it is a contaminated dharma or an uncontaminated dharma, whether it is a dharma with karmic retribution or a dharma without karmic retribution, it is impermanent and also not lost.
Why is it so?
If a dharma is impermanent, then it is a characteristic of movement, it is a characteristic of emptiness.
For this reason, ÅšÄriputra!
All conditioned dharmas are impermanent and also not lost.
Furthermore, ÅšÄriputra!
All dharmas are neither permanent nor extinguished.
ÅšÄriputra said:
What dharmas are neither permanent nor extinguished?
SubhÅ«ti said:
Form is neither permanent nor extinguished.
Why is it so?
Its nature is so of itself.
Feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness are neither permanent nor extinguished.
Why is it so?
Its nature is so of itself.
Up to the feeling produced by the condition of the mind consciousness is neither permanent nor extinguished.
Why is it so?
Its nature is so of itself.
For this reason, ÅšÄriputra!
All dharmas are born from the combination of causes and conditions and have no self-nature.
As ÅšÄriputra said:
Why is it that form is ultimately unborn, and feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness are ultimately unborn?
SubhÅ«ti said:
Form is not a created dharma, and feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness are not created dharmas.
Why is this?
Because the creator cannot be apprehended.
ÅšÄriputra!
The eye is not a created dharma.
Why is this?
Because the creator cannot be apprehended;
up to the mind is also like this.
The eye element up to the mind contact as a condition for the arising of feeling is also like this.
Furthermore, ÅšÄriputra!
All dharmas are neither arising nor created.
Why is this?
Because the creator cannot be apprehended.
For this reason, ÅšÄriputra!
Form is ultimately unborn, and feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness are ultimately unborn.
As ÅšÄriputra said:
'For what reason is that which is ultimately non-arisen not called form?
Is that which is ultimately non-arisen not called feeling, perception, volitional formations, or consciousness?'
SubhÅ«ti said:
The nature of form is empty, and that emptiness is without arising, without ceasing, without abiding or transforming;
The nature of feeling, perception, volitional formations, and consciousness is empty, and that emptiness is without arising, without ceasing, without abiding or transforming.
The nature of the eyes up to all conditioned phenomena is empty, and that emptiness is without arising, without ceasing, without abiding or transforming.
For this reason, ÅšÄriputra!
That which is ultimately non-arisen is not called form;
That which is ultimately non-arisen is not called feeling, perception, volitional formations, or consciousness.
As ÅšÄriputra said:
'For what reason should one teach this prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ to a dharma that is ultimately non-arisen?'
SubhÅ«ti said:
The ultimate non-arising is precisely prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, and prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ is precisely the ultimate non-arising. PrajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ and the ultimate non-arising are non-dual and indivisible.
For this reason, ÅšÄriputra,
should I teach prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ to the ultimately non-arisen?
As ÅšÄriputra said:
'For what reason, apart from the ultimately non-arisen, is there no bodhisattva practice of anuttarÄ samyaksaá¹ƒbodhi?'
SubhÅ«ti said:

When bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas practice prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, they do not see the ultimately non-arisen as different from prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, nor do they see the ultimately non-arisen as different from the bodhisattva. The ultimately non-arisen and the bodhisattva are non-dual and indivisible.
They do not see the ultimately non-arisen as different from form.
Why is this?
Because the ultimately non-arisen and form are non-dual and indivisible;
One does not see the ultimate non-arising as different from feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness.
Why is it so?
The ultimate non-arising and feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness are non-dual and indivisible.
Up to all kinds of cognition are also like this.
For this reason, ÅšÄriputra!
Apart from the ultimate non-arising, there is no bodhisattva practice of supreme perfect enlightenment.
As ÅšÄriputra said:

'For what causes and conditions does a bodhisattva, upon hearing this teaching, not become disheartened, regretful, shocked, frightened, or terrified? This is called a bodhisattva practicing prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ?'
SubhÅ«ti said:

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas do not see any phenomena that have the characteristic of cognition. They see all phenomena as like a dream, like an illusion, like a flame, like a shadow, like an echo, and like a magical creation.
ÅšÄriputra!
For this reason, when bodhisattvas hear this teaching, their minds do not become deflated, regretful, frightened, terrified, or fearful.
The treatise says:
All dharmas have no intrinsic nature means using emptiness of nature to refute the individual natures of all dharmas.
Here, SubhÅ«ti himself says:
All dharmas arise from a combination, and have no intrinsic nature.
It is like the combination of the five aggregates and other dharmas, as well as the wholesome dharmas such as the six perfections, from which the name of a bodhisattva emerges;
Because this bodhisattva arises from the combination of conditioned factors and causes, he is not composed of a single dharma, and for this reason he is said to be a provisional name.

This multitude of dharmas also arises from the combination of causes and conditions. For example, the eye consciousness arises from the combination of causes and conditions such as the eye, form, light, space, and the mind that desires to see. In this case, one cannot say that the eye is the seer, nor that the consciousness is the seer, nor that the form is the seer, nor that the light is the seer.
If the eye, form, consciousness, etc. each cannot see, then seeing should not exist in the combination [of causes and conditions].
Therefore, the dharma of seeing is ultimately empty, like an illusion, like a dream.
All dharmas are also like this.
Furthermore, all dharmas are impermanent and also not lost. Impermanence breaks through the inverted view of permanence, and not losing breaks through the inverted view of annihilation.
This dharma of impermanence and not losing is the gateway to entering the true nature of reality. Therefore, SubhÅ«ti said to ÅšÄriputra:
Impermanence is precisely the characteristic of movement, it is precisely the characteristic of emptiness.
All dharmas are also like this.
Furthermore, all dharmas are neither permanent nor extinguished is as explained in the latter meaning of the eighteen emptinesses.
Form is ultimately unborn means that the agent, the one who arises, and the one who gives rise to the five aggregates cannot be obtained.
Furthermore, the characteristic of arising cannot be obtained, as explained in the previous refutation of arising.
All dharmas are also like this.
Why is it said that if form is unborn, it is not form, not feeling, perception, formation, or consciousness? Here SubhÅ«ti himself explains:
Form arises from causes and conditions, has no intrinsic nature, and always has the characteristic of emptiness.
If a dharma always has the characteristic of emptiness, that dharma has no characteristic of arising, no characteristic of ceasing, and no characteristic of abiding and changing.
Feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness are also like this.
Therefore, the dharma of the characteristic of non-arising is precisely the unconditioned, not the characteristic of the conditioned.
The remaining dharmas are also like this.

If ultimately non-arising, to whom should one teach prajÃ±Ä? Ultimately non-arising is precisely the true nature of all dharmas, and the true nature of all dharmas is precisely prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ. How can one use prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ to teach prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ?
If apart from this ultimate non-arising there were a bodhisattva, one should teach prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ;
This bodhisattva, prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, and ultimate non-arising are non-dual and indivisible. How can one teach one who practices apart from ultimate non-arising?
The above has already explained this in combination.

The bodhisattva, hearing this, does not sink or regret means that the bodhisattva does not see self, sentient beings, up to the knower and seer, nor any speaker or listener, no false speech or correct speech, nor any non-speech.

Knowing that all dharmas arise from the combination of causes and conditions, and cease when those conditions are separated, there is no one who gives rise to them and no one who causes them to cease, so they are not afraid, terrified, overwhelmed, or regretful.
Bodhisattvas know that all dharmas are false, deceptive, unreal, and indeterminate;
Even if they were to face death and fall into AvÄ«ci Hell, their minds would still not waver, let alone be frightened by hearing false sounds.
It is like a person who sees frightening things in a dream, but when they wake up, they have no fear in their mind, knowing that the dream deceives the mind and has no real substance;

Bodhisattvas are also like this. Entering the dream-like mind of the world, they see there are frightening things, but when they attain the realization of the true nature of dharmas, they have no fear;
Knowing that all dharmas are merely false and deceptive, without any reality.
Furthermore, it is like a magician. Although the wise see [his illusions], their minds are not deceived, knowing that they are deceptive phenomena;
Bodhisattvas are also like this. Knowing that all dharmas are like illusions, able to deceive the human mind, and that there is nothing real in them, therefore they are not afraid.
Like a mirage, a shadow, a transformation, and so forth.
ã€Sutraã€‘ Subhuti addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-honored One!

When bodhisattva-mahasattvas practice prajnaparamita and contemplate dharmas in this way, at that time bodhisattva-mahasattvas do not accept form, do not view form, do not dwell in form, do not cling to form, and do not say this is form;
They also do not accept, view, dwell in, or cling to feeling, perception, formation, or consciousness, and also do not say this is feeling, perception, formation, or consciousness.
They do not accept, view, dwell in, or cling to the eye, and also do not say this is the eye;
The ear, nose, tongue, body;
The mind also does not accept, view, dwell in, or cling to it, and also does not say this is the mind.
The perfection of giving is not accepted, not seen, not dwelled in, not attached to, and it is also not said to be the perfection of giving;
The perfection of morality, the perfection of patience, the perfection of diligence, the perfection of meditation;
The perfection of wisdom is not accepted, not shown, not dwelled in, not attached to, and it is also not said to be the perfection of wisdom.
Internal emptiness is not accepted, not shown, not dwelled in, not attached to, and it is also not said to be internal emptiness;
Up to the emptiness of non-existence of nature, it is the same.
Furthermore, World-Honored One!

When bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas practice the perfection of wisdom, the four mindfulnesses are not accepted, not shown, not dwelled in, not attached to, and it is also not said to be the four mindfulnesses;
Up to the eighteen distinctive abilities of the Buddha are not accepted, not shown, not dwelled in, not attached to, and it is also not said to be the eighteen distinctive abilities of the Buddha.
all samÄdhi gateways and all dhÄraá¹‡Ä« gateways;
up to all types of cognition, he does not accept, demonstrate, abide, or cling to them, and also does not say 'this is all types of cognition.'
Furthermore, World-Honored One!
When bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas practice prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, they do not see form, up to they do not see all types of cognition.
Why is it so?
Form is not produced, and this is not form;
feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness;
consciousness is not produced, and this is not consciousness.
The eye is not produced, and this is not the eye;
the ear, nose, tongue, body;
the mind is not produced, and this is not the mind.
The perfection of giving is not produced, and this is not the perfection of giving;
up to the perfection of wisdom is not produced, and this is not the perfection of wisdom.
Why is it so?
Form and non-production are non-dual and indivisible;
up to the perfection of wisdom and non-arising are non-dual and indivisible.
The non-arising of inner emptiness is not inner emptiness;
up to the non-arising of the emptiness of non-existence of non-existence is not the emptiness of non-existence of non-existence, why is it so?
Inner emptiness up to the emptiness of non-existence of non-existence and non-arising are non-dual and indivisible.
World-Honored One!
The non-arising of the four establishments of mindfulness is not the four establishments of mindfulness, why is it so?
The four establishments of mindfulness and non-arising are non-dual and indivisible.
Why is it so?
World-Honored One!
This non-arising dharma is neither one, nor two, nor three, nor different.
Therefore, the four establishments of mindfulness and non-arising are non-dual and indivisible.
Up to the non-arising of the eighteen distinctive abilities of a buddha is not the eighteen distinctive abilities of a buddha.
Why is it so?
The eighteen distinctive abilities of a buddha and non-arising are non-dual and indivisible.
Why is it so?
World-Honored One!
This non-arising dharma is neither one, nor two, nor three, nor different.
For this reason, the eighteen distinctive abilities of a buddha do not arise, and are not the eighteen distinctive abilities of a buddha.
World-Honored One!
As non-arising is not thusness,
up to the nature of the inconceivable does not arise, and is not the nature of the inconceivable.
World-Honored One!
This anuttara-samyak-sambodhi does not arise, and is not omniscience;
all-inclusive cognition does not arise, and is not all-inclusive cognition.
Why is it so?
Because this anuttara-samyak-sambodhi, up to all-inclusive cognition, and non-arising are non-dual and indivisible.
Why is it so?
World-Honored One!
This non-arising dharma is neither one, nor two, nor three, nor different.
For this reason, up to all-inclusive cognition does not arise, and is not all-inclusive cognition.
World-Honored One!
The non-extinguishing characteristic of form is not form.
Why is it so?
Form and the characteristic of non-extinction are non-dual and indivisible.
Why is it so?
World-Honored One!
This non-extinguishing Dharma is neither one nor two, neither three nor different.
For this reason, the characteristic of non-extinction of form is not form;
feeling, perception, formation,
and consciousness are not consciousness.
Why is it so?
Consciousness and non-extinction are non-dual and indivisible.
Why is it so?
World-Honored One!
This non-extinguishing Dharma is neither one nor two, neither three nor different. For this reason, the characteristic of non-extinction of consciousness is not consciousness.

The perfections of giving, morality, patience, diligence, concentration, and wisdom, from inner emptiness to emptiness of non-existence and existence, and the four mindfulnesses up to the eighteen distinctive abilities of the Buddha, are also like this.
World-Honored One!

For this reason, the sense-field of form is not counted as a non-dual dharma, the sense-fields of feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness are not counted as non-dual dharmas, up to and including the knowledge of all modes, which is not counted as a non-dual dharma.
The treatise says:
SubhÅ«ti addressed the Buddha, saying:
The bodhisattva is able to contemplate the dharmas in this way, and within the five aggregates, there are five kinds of correct contemplation practices:
Namely, not grasping, because within the five aggregates, there is the fire of impermanence that can burn the mind.

Not looking means not grasping at characteristics. Not only contemplating the faults of impermanence, etc., but also contemplating the emptiness of these five aggregates, because one does not grasp at characteristics.
Not dwelling means not relying on the five aggregates, because one fears the thieves of afflictions coming and does not dare to dwell for long;
It is like an empty village where thieves dwell - the wise should not stay there for long.

Not attached means that if the five aggregates have even one fault, one should not be attached to them, let alone being attached to hunger, thirst, cold, heat, old age, sickness, death, etc. in the body, and worry, fear, jealousy, anger, etc. in the mind, and falling into the three evil paths in the next life!
All are impermanent, suffering, empty, and without self, and cannot be controlled;
How can one be attached to such innumerable faults?
Not saying this is form means not using wrong views to say that form is either permanent or impermanent, etc., not saying that the five aggregates have such definite characteristics.
Up to the knowledge of all modes is also like this.
Why is it so?
In form, practicing the five kinds of right practices, these five aggregates are all without the characteristic of arising, all have one characteristic, one characteristic is no characteristic;
If there is no characteristic, then there are no five aggregates.
Up to the knowledge of all modes is also like this.
If the characteristic of non-arising of all dharmas and prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ are non-dual and not separate,
attaining this non-arising mind is prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ;
attaining prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ is knowing that all dharmas are non-arising and non-ceasing.
For this reason, prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ is non-arising, non-dual, and not separate.
Furthermore, SubhÅ«ti himself gives the reason, namely, that this non-arising dharma has no single characteristic, no dual characteristic, no three, and is not different.
Why is it so?
Because all dharmas and non-arising are of a single characteristic.
Up to all-inclusive cognition, it is also like this.
Like non-arising, non-ceasing is also like this.
Question:
Why does the last [part] say form, up to all-inclusive cognition, enter the category of non-dual dharmas?
Answer:
If a bodhisattva has not yet broken through form, then love and other afflictions arise, and they become attached to form and so forth;
If one destroys form, one gives rise to wrong views and becomes attached to the emptiness of form, etc.
Now, because of the wisdom of emptiness regarding the function of form, etc., they are all empty and non-dual.
These dharmas are false and unreal because they are included in the internal and external sense bases, so they are called two;
Form, etc., up to omniscience, are apart from these two, called non-dual.
Now SubhÅ«ti, out of compassion for sentient beings and for the benefit of all bodhisattvas, says:
These dharmas are non-dual, entering the category of non-dual dharmas.Here is the corrected and aligned text:
